subject: Re: [junit] Re: equals is "commutative" ... so
msgSnippet: Thomas: This may be a case of mistaken intent -- I don t believe that assertEquals was intended to test the validity of an equals() implementation, but
messageBody:
Thomas:

This may be a case of mistaken intent -- I don't believe that
"assertEquals" was intended to "test" the validity of an "equals()"
implementation, but rather to simply test if two objects/primitives/etc...
are equal. Like testing that the result of an operation is equal to the
expected result.

I seem to remember someone submitting a set of assert methods that can be
used to verify an "equals" implementation.

When I've implemented equals/hashcode/compareTo I've hand coded the tests
(ok, I do some cut & paste, too).

Ken

At 05:10 AM 5/20/2003, you wrote:

>Fine but I really feel equals should behave so.
>The question is more do you have a need for NON-commutative equals.
>
>As the testing of the equality's implementation is better done by :
>
> [code]
> testAequalsBimplementation ()
> {
> assertTrue ("A is not equal to B", a.equals (b));
> }
> testBequalsAimplementation ()
> {
> assertTrue ("B is not equal to A", b.equals (a));
> }
> [/code]
>
>The REAL / FULL equality is therefore better evaluated by either the
>combination of both... and that's precisely what the assertEquals
>should test IMHO !
>
>Equality is really equivalent to test both cases :
> [code]
> testAequalsB ()
> {
> assertEquals ("A is not equals to B", a, b);
> }
> [/code]
>
>but I believe many people don't have the need to have equals() being
>implemented too extensively & therefore are pleased with most failure
>returned to have an acceptable implemetation.
>
>
>Thomas,
>
>
>
>--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, "Paul Zabelin" <pavel_zabelin@3...>
>wrote:
> > --- In junit@yahoogroups.com, "Thomas SMETS" <tsmets@l...> wrote:
> > > I am wondering why the assertEquals is not doing a more thorough
> > > validation.
> > >
> > > This would make sure that :
> > > A = B <=> B = A
> > > which is trivial "math" & sounds to me like a normal default
> > behavior
> > > (though slower).
> >
> > Could it be a candidate for ThoroughDecorator or ThoroughTestCase?
> > After couple of years of using junit I had never had a need to
>assert
> > on commutative equal. If you want to test your own Object's equals,
> > then may be you can just create several test
> > checking "commutativeness"?
>
